channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Fighting Ebola, and the Mud
item.description: Liberia’s impassable roads are preventing effective diagnosis and treatment.
item.dc:creator: By KARIN HUSTER

item.title: Despite U.S. Pressure, Travel Ban Stands for American Couple Held in Qatar
item.description: A Qatar appeals court said it would rule Nov. 30 on the couple’s conviction in the death of their adopted daughter nearly two years ago.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Shipwreck Survivors Recount a Deadly Journey From Middle East to Europe
item.description: Four days had passed since their overcrowded migrant boat had capsized in the Mediterranean, after being rammed in an apparent quarrel between smugglers. They were now weak and hallucinating.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ibrahim and Mohammed Awadallah and Mamoun Doghmosh, from left, on the shore in Malta, where they ended up after a smuggling boat capsized.

item.title: Paris Journal: For Paris ‘Cataphiles,’ the Secret Is Out on Their Cherished Underground
item.description: A secretive community of street artists, history buffs and other Parisians regularly prowl a network of abandoned tunnels and chambers.
item.dc:creator: By AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Pakistani Government Suspends License of ARY News
item.description: Analysts said that the 15-day suspension seemed aimed at curtailing coverage that has been increasingly critical of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Unity on Eurozone Growth Eludes Germany and France
item.description: Meeting in Berlin, the French and German finance and economy ministers said only that they had agreed to come up with economic proposals by Dec. 1.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING and LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Wolfgang Schäuble, left, the German finance minister, with Michel Sapin, the French finance minister, at a news conference Monday.

item.title: A Beloved Pakistani Philanthropist Falls Prey to Karachi’s Criminals
item.description: Robbers targeted the home and headquarters of Abdul Sattar Edhi, taking more than $1 million and gold jewelry that had been donated to his foundation.
item.dc:creator: By SABA IMTIAZ

item.title: World Briefing: Russia Frees Activist Who Was Investigating Soldiers’ Deaths
item.description: The activist, who sought to document the deaths of soldiers believed to have been sent to fight in Ukraine, was released for health reasons, an advocacy group said.
item.dc:creator: By ALEXANDRA ODYNOVA

item.title: Turkey Says It Will Aid Kurdish Forces in Fight for Kobani
item.description: Turkey, in an apparent shift, said that it would facilitate the movement of Iraqi Kurdish forces to the embattled Syrian city of Kobani to join the battle against militants.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.media:description: Turkish Army tanks took up positions Sunday near the Turkish-Syrian border opposite the Syrian town of Kobani.

item.title: More Jewish Settlers Move Into East Jerusalem Neighborhood
item.description: An earlier influx of settlers to the Silwan area had been condemned by the Obama administration as “provocative.”
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Dozens Are Killed in Attacks on Shiite Targets in Iraq
item.description: A flurry of attacks included a quadruple car bombing near two of the holiest shrines in Shiite Islam, killing 40, officials said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: W.H.O. Declares Nigeria Free of Ebola
item.description: The announcement called Nigeria’s effort a “spectacular success story” but warned that the country, Africa’s most populous, cannot relax its defenses.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Awaiting Oscar Pistorius Sentencing, South Africa Wrangles Over Complex Issues
item.description: Judge Thokozile Matilda Masipa is expected to begin handing down a sentence on Tuesday to Oscar Pistorius in the death of his girlfriend.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Judge Thokozile Matilda Masipa at a sentencing hearing for Oscar Pistorius last week.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Giant Spider and Dragon-Horse Duel in Beijing Performance
item.description: A battle between two mechanical titans, a fire-breathing dragon-horse and a giant spider, helped commemorate the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations between China and France.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Hong Kong Leader Reaffirms Tough Stance on Elections and Economic Discontent
item.description: Leung Chun-ying, Hong Kong’s chief executive, has shown no sign of softening his Beijing-endorsed stance regarding open elections in the city.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Leung Chun-ying, the chief executive of Hong Kong, during a news conference last week.

item.title: Power Up: For South Korea, E-Sports Is National Pastime
item.description: The extent to which video games have become part of mainstream culture in South Korea may be a sign of things to come in the West.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL MOZUR
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Playing League of Legends at PC Cafe Con, a PC bang in Seoul. A vibrant community of gamers has grown in South Korea, largely thanks to PC bangs that utilized telecommunications and Internet infrastructure the country invested in after the Asian financial crisis hit.

item.title: Two Women Resign Japan Cabinet, a Blow to Abe
item.description: Hurt by election funding scandals, the two were the highest-profile women in Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s government, part of his goal to empower women.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Nepal Tragedy Reverberates Across Borders
item.description: As rescue efforts ended, the international dimension of the disaster and the toll it took on Nepal’s own people, many of them guides, came into focus.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Family members of Nepali trekking porters waited outside a morgue in Katmandu on Monday.

item.title: Albanian Premier Postpones Serbia Trip After Episode at Soccer Match
item.description: Prime Minister Edi Rama was scheduled to visit Belgrade, the Serbian capital, on Wednesday, the first trip there by an Albanian government leader since 1946.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Donates $6 Million for Food Aid in Ebola Fight
item.description: China, a leading trading partner to many African countries, has been urged to take a more active role in the Ebola fight.
item.dc:creator: By JESS MACY YU
item.media:description: Residents lining up for rice rations at a distribution center in Dolo, Liberia. The World Health Organization has warned that the Ebola epidemic is contributing to food shortages.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Toronto on a Bender
item.description: Dirtiness and savagery are the new normal in the mayoral campaign.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN MARCHE
item.media:description: Mayoral candidates Doug Ford, left, and John Tory have both indulged in the uniquely charmless rhetoric of rich white men calling each other privileged.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Germany Without Angst? That Worries Me.
item.description: After the era of neoliberalism, the country might be falling for another Zeitgeist: the sinfulness of making debt.
item.dc:creator: By JOCHEN BITTNER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Hong Kong and Prague, Notes of Support and Windows on Unrest
item.description: Colorful sticky notes adorn a wall in Hong Kong expressing support for the democracy demonstrators of Occupy Central, echoing the Lennon Wall in Prague, which has responded with its own messages.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Joko Widodo Is Sworn In as Indonesian President
item.description: Mr. Joko, who was born in a slum, is the first Indonesian president not to have emerged from the country’s political elite or to have been a general.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: U.S. Airdrops Weapons and Supplies to Kurds Fighting in Kobani
item.description: On top of recent airstrikes against the Islamic State, the move reflects the importance of the Syrian town on the Turkish border.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
